newsitem.title: USA: BASEBALL-AMERICAN WAS FATHER OF YANKEES' IRABU: NEW YORK TIMES.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-AMERICAN WAS FATHER OF YANKEES' IRABU: NEW YORK TIMES.

text.p: Hideki Irabu, the Japanese pitching sensation for the New York Yankees, is actually the biological son of an American, the New York Times reported on Tuesday.
The Times quoted the man who raised Irabu, restaurant manager Ichiru Irabu, as saying that the 28-year-old baseball star was the son of his wife, Kazue, and an American man he declined to name.
The paper said there has been speculation throughout Japan that Irabu's father was an American serviceman, but the family had not spoken before about Irabu's parentage.
Ichiro Irabu told the Times that the subject was too sensitive for him to talk about at length, saying only that he became Hideki's stepfather soon after Hideki was born.
He declined to say whether the pitcher knew his real father or whether the man is alive, the article said.

Irabu made a sensational major-league debut for the Yankees Thursday, striking out nine batters in 6-2/3 innings in a victory over the Detroit Tigers before a big, festive Yankee Stadium crowd. He was scheduled to start Tuesday afternoon at Yankee Stadium against the Cleveland Indians.

The big right-hander, who owns a blazing fastball which he throws at varying speeds along with a baffling splitter and deceptive changeup, has grabbed headlines in a City Hall appearance with the mayor and a parking lot collision with the car of Yankee boss George Steinbrenner.

Irabu signed a four-year, $12.8 million contract with the Yankees after they struck a deal with the San Diego Padres, who had acquired his rights from Chiba Lotte of the Japanese Pacific League. He insisted he would play for no major-league team except the Yankees.
